pr_title: Test current JDBC driver against old Presto releases

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think we should run the tests in old versions of the project. The "source of truth" for tests should be what's in trunk right now. The problems with running old test code are:

If there are bug in the old tests, there's no way to "fix" them -- we can't go back in time and patch an old presto test jar
It relies on treating the structure of the tests as an API (it's not!). If we refactor the test code in master, the old tests may stop running at all.

If we want more test coverage, or tests targeted to a specific version, we should augment the current test library and enable tests conditionally based on the version being targeted.
(I'm assuming this is what this does based on similar structure for the other jdbc driver tests, which I think we should change)
timeline.author: martint
timeline.diffHunk:

+
+        <dependency>
+            <groupId>io.prestosql</groupId>
+            <artifactId>presto-jdbc</artifactId>
+            <scope>test</scope>
+            <version>${project.version}</version>

replies.bodyText:
I don't think we should run the tests in old versions of the project. The "source of truth" for tests should be what's in trunk right now

This code does not run old tests. The version of tests which is run is the one living on the trunk. What this PR does is running those tests against older versions of Presto servers run in docker.
I even had to disable a few test assertions, for queries which did not work before parametric timestamp was introduced (see: f3449b3)

We now have 2 TestJdbcResultSetCompatibility classes:
BaseTestJdbcResultSet (io.prestosql.jdbc)
- TestJdbcResultSetCompatibility (io.prestosql)
- TestJdbcResultSet (io.prestosql.jdbc)
   - TestJdbcResultSetCompatibility (io.prestosql)


why is the inheritance hierarchy uneven? Maybe it could be flat now? (disregard if it cannot)
2. the TestJdbcResultSetCompatibility classes could be renamed to better indicate their specifics, without need to lookup module name (which is long and easy to be stripped out of view)

timeline.bodyText:
Current version is tested by io.prestosql.jdbc.TestJdbcResultSet.
I understand you need this to run the test from intellij (to test the test),
so please add an appropriate comment. Otherwise it looks like "this test
past versions... or it doesn't"
Also, how do we actually verify the test works?
Would it work if we allowed currentVersionString == null only when some
additional sys property is set? You would set it manually when running from IDE
and CI or when running from maven would use the JDBC jar and fall into
currentVersionString != null category.
Also, maybe we can simplify this by baking in the current version via resources?
Like here
https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/cd061b3410c752253d64f096176bf226a3dea11a/presto-product-tests-launcher/src/main/java/io/prestosql/tests/product/launcher/cli/Launcher.java#L170-L172

replies.bodyText:
Without group-by-instances="true" tests are grouped by test method. Like that:
instance_a.testA()
instance_b.testA()
instance_c.testA()
instance_a.testB()
instance_b.testB()
instancd_c.testB()

This is very resource intensive as each initialized instance is separate running docker instance.
With this flag only one docker instance is running as exutions are grouped by instance.
I will see if hack to enforce single threaded execution may solves this one too.
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
This is very resource intensive as each initialized instance is separate running docker instance.

timeline.bodyText:
obviously, this means

when current is 341-SNAPSHOT, we test aginst 340, 337, ...
when we do the 341 release, we will be testing against 341, 338

Now, what if 338 does not pass the test for some reason?
The release procedure may result in the master branch turning red.
hm... maybe TESTED_VERSIONS_GRANULARITY is not so good an idea after all?
or maybe the above is actually OK?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
obviously, this means

when current is 341-SNAPSHOT, we test aginst 340, 337, ...
when we do the 341 release, we will be testing against 341, 338


Hmm why so? 340, 337, 334 in both cases. Am I missing sth?
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: sorry, wasn;'t clear. Right after the release, we switch to 342-SNAPSHOT, and then we pick different versions
replies.author: findepi

replies.bodyText:
Yeah. It looks like (highly unlikely) we can not notice that given released version is not really compatible with one of the past jdbc drivers.
Maybe if release is non-snapshot we should use GRANRALITY=1 and test more past versions?
Or aren't we ever running a PR automation when version is non snapshot?
I am fine with dropping granularity here altogether, but it will make tests slightly longer as we probably want to cover servers released in a year or so. Which translates to 10-20 versions.
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
It seems that to trigger issue you mention above we would need to have situation that all below are true:

driver N is incompatible with server N-2
driver N-1 compatible with server N-2
driver N is compatible with server N-1

so we need non-transitive compatibility. Possible but, I would not expect it happen in reality.
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
so we need non-transitive compatibility. Possible but, I would not expect it happen in reality.

or if/exclusion in the test that makes the test pass (not fail) for a specific version
OK, we can keep as is.

timeline.message: Guard JDBC tests against Presto server version
Test current JDBC driver against old Presto releases
Allow specifying Presto server version to be tested via env
